hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Sha'bi: The Hajjaj sent me to Rutbil and he gave me a gift. He said to me: 'What is this dye? Hair is only white or black.' I said: 'It is a Sunnah (practice).'

Discussion about hair dyeing practices
Al-Sha'bi's testimony that dyeing hair is a Sunnah

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated about al-Sha'bi: He would not leave his gathering until he said: 'I bear witness that there is no god except Allah, alone without partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger, and I bear witness that the religion is as He legislated, and I bear witness that Islam is as He described, and I bear witness that the Book is as He revealed, and that the saying is as He narrated, and I bear witness that Allah is the Clear Truth. When he rose to leave, he said: May Allah mention Muhammad from us with salutation.'

narrators.name: Khalaf ibn Tamim ibn Malik
narrators.full_name: Khalaf ibn Tamim ibn Malik (genealogy incomplete in sources)

narrators.name: al-Sha'bi
narrators.alternative_names: Amir ibn Sharahi, Abu Amr al-Sha'bi

chainIssues: Both Khalaf ibn Tamim and Tamim ibn Malik are not well-documented (majhul al-hal)
The transmission term 'an (عن) used with al-Sha'bi adds ambiguity

potential_issues.issue: Khalaf ibn Tamim ibn Malik is of limited documentation (majhul al-hal) and his father Tamim ibn Malik is similarly not well-established
potential_issues.impact: The chain relies on two lesser-known narrators which significantly weakens the reliability of transmission, though neither appears to have been severely criticized

potential_issues.issue: Ambiguous transmission term 'an (عن) used with al-Sha'bi
potential_issues.impact: While al-Sha'bi himself is reliable, the use of 'an introduces potential for indirect transmission which is not ideal

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Sha'bi: A man said near al-Sha'bi: 'Said Allah (qala Allah).' Al-Sha'bi said: 'Why do you not say: Said Allah?'

Teaching about proper terminology in religious discourse

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Bakr ibn Shu'ayb ibn al-Habbab: I heard Amir al-Sha'bi, and my father asked him: 'Why is your lower garment hanging loose, O Abu Amr?' He was wearing a white linen lower garment with stripes. Al-Sha'bi said: 'There is nothing here to hold it up (referring to his buttocks).' My father asked him: 'How long have you been like this, O Abu Amr?' Al-Sha'bi answered with poetry, reciting: 'My soul complains to me of approaching death, and I have carried you seven years after seventy years. If you produce false hope, O my soul, the three will make eighty complete.' Abu Bakr ibn Shu'ayb said: He was seventy-seven years old and was composing poetry.

hadiths.english_translation: It is reported that al-Sha'bi died in Kufa in the year 105 and he was 77 years old. It is also reported: It is reported through Abu Nu'aym al-Fadl ibn Dukayn that al-Sha'bi died in the year 104.

hadiths.english_translation: It is similarly reported: Said ibn Jamil narrated from Aban ibn Umar ibn Uthman that al-Sha'bi died in the year 104. Muhammad ibn Sa'd said, and others said: He died in the year 103, and he died on the same Friday as Abu Burdah ibn Abi Musa.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by 'Asim: I informed al-Hasan of al-Sha'bi's death, and he said: 'May Allah have mercy on him, indeed he was in a noble place from Islam.' It is said: al-Sha'bi died suddenly.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: He said to Sa'id ibn Jubayr: 'From whom are you?' I said: 'From Bani Asad.' He said: 'Are you from their Arabs or from their clients?' I said: 'No, but from their clients.' He said: 'Then say: I am from those upon whom Allah has bestowed favor from Bani Asad.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: Abu Mas'ud al-Badri saw me on the day of festival while I had a forelock, and he said: 'O boy or O little boy, there is no prayer on a day like this before the prayer of the leader (Imam), so pray after his prayer two units and lengthen the recitation.' Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: Sa'id ibn Jubayr also narrated from Ibn Umar, Ibn Abbas and others.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: Ibn Abbas said to Sa'id ibn Jubayr: 'Narrate.' Sa'id said: 'I narrate while you are present?' Ibn Abbas said: 'Is it not a blessing from Allah upon you that you narrate while I am a witness? If you are correct, that is so, and if you make an error, I will teach you.' Also narrated: Sa'id ibn Jubayr was questioning Ibn Abbas before he became blind, and he was not able to write with him. But when Ibn Abbas became blind, he wrote. When Ibn Abbas was informed of this, he became angry.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: Sometimes I came to Ibn Abbas and wrote in my parchment until I filled it, and I wrote in my sandal until I filled it, and I wrote in my palm. And sometimes I came to him and did not write any hadith until I went back, no one asked him about anything.

potential_issues.issue: This hadith contains conflicting reports: one saying Sa'id used to write, and another saying he disliked those who write hadith
potential_issues.impact: The contradictory nature of the two reports within the same hadith entry raises questions about accuracy or possibly different contexts

potential_issues.issue: Ja'far ibn Abi al-Mughira uses ambiguous transmission term 'an (عن)
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'an suggests potential for indirect transmission in both parts of the narration

Topics: Sa'id ibn Jubayr's practice of writing hadith from Ibn Abbas
Conflicting reports about Sa'id's attitude toward hadith writers

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: 'I used to ask Ibn Umar secretly in a register, and if he knew about it, it would be the decisive matter between me and him. He said: I asked him about oath of continence (al-Ilaa'), and he said: 'Do you want to say: Ibn Umar said, and Ibn Umar said?' I said: 'Yes, and we are pleased with your saying and content.' He said: 'The commanders speak about this (matter).'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: When we disagreed about something in Kufa, I wrote it down, until I met Ibn Umar, then I asked him about it.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: A man came to Ibn Umar asking about a matter of inheritance, and he said: 'Go to Sa'id ibn Jubayr, for he is more knowledgeable in calculation than me, and he calculates from it what I calculate.'

chainIssues: Aslam and Sa'id both use 'an

Topics: Ibn Umar referring people to Sa'id ibn Jubayr for knowledge of inheritance calculations

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: The inscription on my ring was 'Azz rabbi wa'qtadara' (My Lord is mighty and powerful). Ibn Umar read it and prohibited me from it, so I erased it and inscribed 'Sa'id ibn Jubayr' on it.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated about Sa'id ibn Jubayr: Ali ibn Husayn asked about Sa'id ibn Jubayr's condition, and when told he was good, Ali said: 'That is a man who used to pass by us, and we would ask him about inheritance matters and other beneficial things. We do not have what these people throw at us (referring to Iraq).'

chainIssues: al-A'mash is known for tadlis (concealment), though he is generally Saduq

potential_issues.issue: al-A'mash (Suleiman ibn Mihran) is known for tadlis (concealment of transmission)
potential_issues.impact: While al-A'mash is generally Saduq and Category 2 mudallis (not severely problematic), tadlis should be noted. The use of حدثنا here is explicit enough to mitigate the concern

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: The companions of Sa'id ibn Jubayr would blame him for narrating hadith. He said: 'I prefer to narrate this to you and your companions than to take it with me to my grave.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ayyub: Sa'id ibn Jubayr narrated a hadith, and I followed him to ask for it again, and he said: 'Not every time do I milk so that I drink.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by 'Ata ibn al-Sa'ib: I came to Sa'id ibn Jubayr, and he said to me: 'The most austere people, and such and such keep asking me until this hour.' Also narrated: 'Affan ibn Muslim and Musa ibn Ismail said: Abd al-Wahid ibn Ziyad narrated to us, who said: Abu Shahab narrated to us: 'Sa'id ibn Jubayr used to tell stories to us twice daily, after the dawn prayer and after the afternoon prayer.'

chainIssues: 'Ata ibn al-Sa'ib suffered from ikhtilat (confusion) in later life

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: A woman wrote to Ibn Abbas after his blindness. He gave the letter to his son, but he confused it. So he gave the parchment to me, and I read it to him. He said to his son: 'Did you not scramble it like the Mudar boy scrambled it?' Also narrated: Yazid ibn Harun said: 'Abd al-Malik ibn Abi Suleiman informed us, from Sa'id ibn Jubayr: that he used to complete the Qur'an every two nights.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Sa'id ibn Jubayr: 'I recited the Qur'an in one unit of prayer in the Sacred House.' Also narrated: Al-Fadl ibn Dukayn said: Al-Hasan ibn Salih narrated to us, from Wifa', that 'Sa'id ibn Jubayr used to come between the sunset and night prayers and recite the Qur'an during Ramadan.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Fadl ibn Dukayn: Qais ibn al-Rabi' said, from al-Sa'b ibn Uthman: 'Sa'id ibn Jubayr said: Not two nights have passed over me since al-Husayn was killed except that I recite the Qur'an in them, except when I am traveling or ill.'

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Arim ibn al-Fadl: Hammad ibn Zayd narrated to us, who said: Abu Hashim narrated, from Sa'id ibn Jubayr: 'I recite most of my portion (of the Qur'an) even while the leader is delivering the sermon on Friday.' Also narrated: Musa ibn Ismail said: Abd al-Wahid ibn Ziyad narrated to us, Abu Shahab said: 'Sa'id ibn Jubayr used to lead us in prayer in Ramadan, and he would return; sometimes he would repeat the verse twice.'
